awd_titl_txt: Elucidating the True Role of Surface Microtexturing in Friction Reduction and Enhanced Convective Heat Transfer
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to elucidate the role that surface microtexturing (roughness) has on friction reduction and convective (flow-based) heat transfer. Understanding flow behavior and heat transfer interactions with microtexturing will have significant impact on the general area of superhydrophobic (water repelling) surfaces, particularly for friction reduction and thermal management purposes. The results of this research should have major implications for microscopic flow systems used in electronics cooling and portable biochemical diagnostics applications, as well as larger scale flow systems used in climate control and power generation applications. This project also provides new classroom materials for courses that the researchers teach as well as outreach activities geared towards elementary school audiences. An undergraduate summer internship program aimed Northeastern University freshmen and sophomores from groups that are underrepresented in STEM fields is being established to prepare them for future careers in engineering. 

The governing physics behind the flow within surface microgeometry for different wetting degrees, gas-liquid interface immobilization, and Re conditions is being studied and analyzed. A multi-task research program is in place that includes thermo-hydraulic and optical diagnostics characterization of microtextured samples, numerical simulations of single and two-phase flow with different boundary conditions, and microgeometry optimization of the microtexturing.  The project is comprised of the following specific thrusts: (1) Development of an experimental infrastructure to characterize pressure-flow rate behavior, slip velocity, fluid/wall temperature, and wall heat flux for different wetting and thermal conditions. These results are being validated against numerical simulations and analysis; (2) Assessment of the friction reduction characteristics of the microtextured samples under varying degrees of wetting due to pressure and temperature effects, and under different degrees of gas-liquid interface immobilization; and (3) Characterization of friction reduction on the convective heat transfer of the microtextured microchannels, addressing the tradeoffs between reduced thermal diffusion in the gap space and enhanced thermal advection due to the friction reduction brought about by said gap spaces.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Fundamentally, this project has elucidated the flow physics governing the frictional characteristics of fully wetted (immersed) surface microtexturing for laminar flow. The regular surface irregularities lead to the formation of recirculating structures within the embedded microgeometries that create a competition between form (pressure) drag and skin (shear) drag. This contrasts with the governing physics of liquid repelling microtexturing, which leads to the liquid interface sitting atop the microgeometries and consequential formation of gas pocket that act as ?shear-free? zones.

The cavities or valleys formed by the regular microgeometry serve as region where recirculating structures form as a result of the main flow over the land regions meandering its way into the trench regions. These recirculating structures induce adverse pressure forces in the vertical sections of the trench regions. Conversely, the recirculation zones act as ?cushions? or ?bearings? for the main flow interactions with the bottom horizontal sections of the valleys, leading to a reduction, and in some instances reversal (favorable), in surface shear stress.

The strength and extent of the recirculating regions is highly dependent on the width-to-depth aspect ratio (AR) of the trench regions and the inertia of the flow as characterized by the Reynolds number (Re). For low aspect ratios (AR<~2) trenches, a single or multiple stacked recirculating regions are formed in the trench, leading to reduced skin friction due to the aforementioned ?cushion? or ?bearing? effect, but increased pressure ?friction?, or more appropriately, drag. As the aspect ratios (AR>~2) of the trench regions increase, the single recirculating region collapses and splits into two smaller ones that sit on the corners of the trenches. The collapse of this main recirculating region leads to a decrease in the adverse pressure drag effects brought by it. Simultaneously, this collapse also allows the main flow to fully wander into the trench regions, interacting with its bottom surface and increasing the skin friction (See Figure 1). The effect of Re on the overall behavior of the flow is not as straightforward but in general the strength of the main recirculating region is proportional to it. As such, the higher Re the larger the decrease in skin friction but also the larger the increase in pressure drag.

These frictional effects of the microtexturing trenches were investigated for both internal and external flows. For internal microchannel flow it was found that the overall effect of the trenches was always to increase the overall friction characteristics of the microchannel as compared to a baseline featureless one. In all instances, the increase in pressure drag friction always overwhelmed any decrease in skin drag friction. For external flow, however, for certain trench geometries and flow conditions, an overall frictional drag reduction was observed. This was particularly true for trenches with AR~1-10. For relatively deep trenches (trench depth to overall plate length ratio, e, of 0.04), the overall friction reduction compared to a featureless flat plate was as high as 10% (See Figure 2).

The numerical simulation and experimental work performed during the lifetime of the project lead to one (1) journal publication (with another one in the works), three (3) conference proceedings, and several oral and poster presentations at various conferences.

Broader Impact:

The knowledge gained in this project has major implications for microfluidic systems in thermal management and portable biochemical diagnostics applications, as well as in larger scale piping and heat transfer systems where enhanced thermal transport with reduced pumping power is desirable. 

In addition, the problems that were tackled in this cross-disciplinary project presented rich engineering, physics, and materials challenges to the graduate and undergraduate students involved. Each of the different participants on the project team had an area of specialty (i.e. experimental setup design and instrumentation, micromanufacturing, and image processing and visualization), and as they worked together they mutually taught and mentored each other in their particular areas of knowledge and expertise. Besides the technical knowledge gained by the participants, their interactions enhanced their collaboration and team working skills. Similarly, they were trained in communication and presentation skills through the published papers and oral presentations they conducted. All the students involved attended weekly individual meetings with the PI. Each student also presented once or twice a semester as part of the PI?s research group weekly meetings. Finally, the PI ensured that at all levels the students were exposed to a mentoring scheme that allowed them not only to receive but also to provide guidance to a fellow project member.

The project provided training and financial support for two (2) Ph.D. students along their graduate studies at Northeastern University. In addition to the graduate students, two (2) undergraduate students were involved and supported by this project. One of the Ph.D. students, as well as one of the undergraduate students, were women.


Last Modified: 06/03/2022
Modified by: Carlos H Hidrovo Chavez
